rCOPPx-y2.memHandModelNotes: Not greater than 60 m from forest (Fitch and Shirer 1971, in FL-GAP 2003).  This species occurs at elevations below 910 meters in a wide variety of terrestrial habitats (Copperhead Species Account, www.dgif.stat.va.us/wildlife). KY has an elevational restrictor of 1500m, but I could not find a citation for that max elevation. Amy Silvano, 29Aug05

habitat_description:
This species is found from western Massachusetts, Connecticut, southeastern New York, west through southern Pennsylvania, southern Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, to Missouri and eastern Kansas, and south to Georgia. Its range also extends into Florida, Mississippi, Louisiana, central and eastern Texas. In Mexico, this species occurs in northern Coahuila and eastern Chihuahua. Copperheads are found in deciduous forest, rock outcrops, floodplains and at the edges of swamps. In the arid southwest, this species is found near permanent streams. Rocks, logs, leaf litter, and stumps are a common surface cover where copperheads are found (Ernst 1992).

SW-	Woodland, desert, and riparian zones in southwestern texas.

GP	-Also in riparian zones of semi or permanent waterways. Texas and Kansas areas of the Great Plains.

SE	-Wet woodlands and along borders of swamps. Dry upland deciduous or coniferous woodlands; deserts with sandy soils and rocky outcrops.
